title: AB 2687
content:
The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 23152 of the Vehicle Code in California prohibits driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs. It is illegal to drive with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or higher. The law also applies to individuals addicted to drugs, except those in approved treatment programs. It is illegal to drive a commercial motor vehicle with 0.04 percent or more of alcohol in the blood. If a chemical test within three hours after driving shows 0.04 percent or more alcohol, it is presumed the person had that level while driving. (e) Starting July 1, 2018, it is illegal to drive with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood when a passenger for hire is in the vehicle. A passenger for hire is someone who pays or is expected to pay for the ride. It is presumed that the person had 0.04% or more alcohol in their blood while driving if a chemical test within three hours after driving shows that level. 
(f) Driving under the influence of any drug is unlawful.
(g) Driving under the combined influence of alcohol and drugs is also unlawful. It is illegal to drive under the influence of any drug or the combined influence of alcohol and drugs. Additionally, driving with a blood alcohol level of 0.08% or more is prohibited if it causes bodily injury to another person. In a prosecution, it is presumed that a person had 0.08% or more alcohol in their blood while driving if a chemical test within three hours confirms the same. Neglecting any duty while driving does not require proof of violating a specific code section. In a prosecution, it is presumed that a person had 0.04% or more alcohol in their blood while driving a commercial vehicle if a chemical test within three hours confirms the same. Neglecting any duty while driving does not require proof of violating a specific code section. Starting July 1, 2018, it is illegal to drive with 0.04% or more alcohol in your blood if a passenger for hire is in the vehicle and causing bodily injury to someone else. A passenger for hire is someone who pays or is expected to pay for the ride. If a chemical test within three hours confirms the alcohol level, it is presumed that the person was over the limit while driving. It is unlawful to drive under the influence of drugs or a combination of alcohol and drugs, causing bodily injury to another person. This new law does not require reimbursement by local agencies or school districts.
